body.p: I am perfectly delighted with the photograph of thee which has just come, addressed in thy handwriting— & with the date June 1 1887, written on it. How well I remember thee in that big comprehensive chair!

It has come as a sort of greeting to my little baby, who will be just two weeks old tomorrow. I held it up for her to look at, but I must truthfully confess that her attention seemed to be more absorbed with her own pink fingers that with the picture! I think
Alys or father must have told thee of the baby's birth, I have been hardly able to write before, & am still in bed—but I can't keep sending a note of thanks for thy photograph, & giving thee at the same time a little news about the wee stranger.
She weighs the immense amount of nine pounds, & spends her days chiefly in eating, sleeping & being adored. She almost never cries, and she sleeps the whole night through. She is very fat and very pretty, with great blue eyes, & a fascinating little dimple. Alas! I am afraid I cannot hide the self-evident fact that I am very proud of her, and think her the most wonderful baby that was ever born. It is no use struggling against Fate. I meant to be strictly impartial in my judgment of her, but "C'est plus for que moi". I think she is a little angel. As for myself—I hope to be up again in a week or so, and quite well and strong. The doctor and nurse say I am making a marvelous recovery—but I do not find it at all hard to imagine physical states of greater bliss than my own. However, the Angel more than makes up for it all.

It is a lovely day—the river is shining in the sunlight & the boys are leaping into the water from the barges & splashing merrily about. Little Ray—the baby—lies cooing in her cot, & if I interpret her soft sounds aright she is sending thee her thanks for making her mother so happy by thy gift.

postscript.p: Please remember me to Mr. Gilchrist if he is with thee.
